reviews.text: ...nice architecture but nothing spectacular. If you happen to be nearby, worth the visit, otherwise...

We stopped by here as it is where our hotel was located, on the same square as the Universitat metro. The building itself is beautiful and constructed in the 1450’s with a great clock tower. Lots of nice restaurants in the streets around it that are really cheap compared to more touristic areas and fantastic food.
We had a personal tour by one of the professors.  Some very grand academic buildings with glorious courtyards.  Lots of students around.  In the center of town.

Opened in 1450 (not any other date you may find on copy T-Shirts) this is a landmark on the opposite side of the shopping strip.

You'll see early architecture,  large Spanish arches and a few well established orange trees in the court yard for 'play lunch'.

There is a small shop that sells original university memorabilia but xxl is not going to be a match.

The foyer features a few nice statues carved into the walls and heaps of sandstone.

To think of the people that had attended here over the ages was sobering.

Take 30 minutes and do a browse...it's free!

Just that, a university with most of the buildings for classes and offices. Those on the Square allow a look inside and the ATMs therein may be cheaper. Some bulletin boards may be of interest for those looking for a tutor or a room to rent.
Can only see the building from outside. It's after Christmas the the street was very quiet. Not many people around here.

This site is down the road from Plaça Catalunya and worth a gander. Inside the central front doors go in a little ways. On your right is an incredibly elaborate staircase, decked out with gaudy paintings and tapestries. You can climb the stairs. 
But then come back down and keep going straight from the front door you came in and you enter a garden which is an oasis of quiet in the bustle of the center of the city. Tall trees and gurgling pond water.  Relax.
